trans-unit.source: Getting WMI Objects Get WmiObject
trans-unit.target: Getting WMI Objects Get WmiObject

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Getting WMI Objects (Get-WmiObject)
trans-unit.target: Getting WMI Objects (Get-WmiObject)

trans-unit.source: Getting WMI Objects (Get-WmiObject)
trans-unit.target: Getting WMI Objects (Get-WmiObject)

trans-unit.source: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) is a core technology for Windows system administration because it exposes a wide range of information in a uniform manner.
trans-unit.target: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) is a core technology for Windows system administration because it exposes a wide range of information in a uniform manner.

trans-unit.source: Because of how much WMI makes possible, the Windows PowerShell cmdlet for accessing WMI objects, **Get-WmiObject**, is one of the most useful for doing real work.
trans-unit.target: Because of how much WMI makes possible, the Windows PowerShell cmdlet for accessing WMI objects, **Get-WmiObject**, is one of the most useful for doing real work.

trans-unit.source: We are going to discuss how to use Get-WmiObject to access WMI objects and then how to use WMI objects to do specific things.
trans-unit.target: We are going to discuss how to use Get-WmiObject to access WMI objects and then how to use WMI objects to do specific things.

trans-unit.source: Listing WMI Classes
trans-unit.target: Listing WMI Classes

trans-unit.source: The first problem most WMI users encounter is trying to find out what can be done with WMI.
trans-unit.target: The first problem most WMI users encounter is trying to find out what can be done with WMI.

trans-unit.source: WMI classes describe the resources that can be managed.
trans-unit.target: WMI classes describe the resources that can be managed.

trans-unit.source: There are hundreds of WMI classes, some of which contain dozens of properties.
trans-unit.target: There are hundreds of WMI classes, some of which contain dozens of properties.

trans-unit.source: **Get-WmiObject** addresses this problem by making WMI discoverable.
trans-unit.target: **Get-WmiObject** addresses this problem by making WMI discoverable.

trans-unit.source: You can get a list of the WMI classes available on the local computer by typing:
trans-unit.target: You can get a list of the WMI classes available on the local computer by typing:

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve the same information from a remote computer by using the ComputerName parameter, specifying a computer name or IP address:
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve the same information from a remote computer by using the ComputerName parameter, specifying a computer name or IP address:

trans-unit.source: The class listing returned by remote computers may vary due to the specific operating system the computer is running and the particular WMI extensions added by installed applications.
trans-unit.target: The class listing returned by remote computers may vary due to the specific operating system the computer is running and the particular WMI extensions added by installed applications.

trans-unit.source: When using Get-WmiObject to connect to a remote computer, the remote computer must be running WMI and, under the default configuration, the account you are using must be in the local administrators group on the remote computer.
trans-unit.target: When using Get-WmiObject to connect to a remote computer, the remote computer must be running WMI and, under the default configuration, the account you are using must be in the local administrators group on the remote computer.

trans-unit.source: The remote system does not need to have Windows PowerShell installed.
trans-unit.target: The remote system does not need to have Windows PowerShell installed.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to administer operating systems that are not running Windows PowerShell, but do have WMI available.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to administer operating systems that are not running Windows PowerShell, but do have WMI available.

trans-unit.source: You can even include the ComputerName when connecting to the local system.
trans-unit.target: You can even include the ComputerName when connecting to the local system.

trans-unit.source: You can use the local computer's name, its IP address (or the loopback address 127.0.0.1), or the WMI-style '.' as the computer name.
trans-unit.target: You can use the local computer's name, its IP address (or the loopback address 127.0.0.1), or the WMI-style '.' as the computer name.

trans-unit.source: If you are running Windows PowerShell on a computer named Admin01 with IP address 192.168.1.90, the following commands will all return the WMI class listing for that computer:
trans-unit.target: If you are running Windows PowerShell on a computer named Admin01 with IP address 192.168.1.90, the following commands will all return the WMI class listing for that computer:

trans-unit.source: Get-WmiObject uses the root/cimv2 namespace by default.
trans-unit.target: Get-WmiObject uses the root/cimv2 namespace by default.

trans-unit.source: If you want to specify another WMI namespace, use the **Namespace** parameter and specify the corresponding namespace path:
trans-unit.target: If you want to specify another WMI namespace, use the **Namespace** parameter and specify the corresponding namespace path:

trans-unit.source: Displaying WMI Class Details
trans-unit.target: Displaying WMI Class Details

trans-unit.source: If you already know the name of a WMI class, you can use it to get information immediately.
trans-unit.target: If you already know the name of a WMI class, you can use it to get information immediately.

trans-unit.source: For example, one of the WMI classes commonly used for retrieving information about a computer is **Win32_OperatingSystem**.
trans-unit.target: For example, one of the WMI classes commonly used for retrieving information about a computer is **Win32_OperatingSystem**.

trans-unit.source: Although we are showing all of the parameters, the command can be expressed in a more succinct way.
trans-unit.target: Although we are showing all of the parameters, the command can be expressed in a more succinct way.

trans-unit.source: The **ComputerName** parameter is not necessary when connecting to the local system.
trans-unit.target: The **ComputerName** parameter is not necessary when connecting to the local system.

trans-unit.source: We show it to demonstrate the most general case and remind you about the parameter.
trans-unit.target: We show it to demonstrate the most general case and remind you about the parameter.

trans-unit.source: The **Namespace** defaults to root/cimv2, and can be omitted as well.
trans-unit.target: The **Namespace** defaults to root/cimv2, and can be omitted as well.

trans-unit.source: Finally, most cmdlets allow you to omit the name of common parameters.
trans-unit.target: Finally, most cmdlets allow you to omit the name of common parameters.

trans-unit.source: With Get-WmiObject, if no name is specified for the first parameter, Windows PowerShell treats it as the **Class** parameter.
trans-unit.target: With Get-WmiObject, if no name is specified for the first parameter, Windows PowerShell treats it as the **Class** parameter.

trans-unit.source: This means the last command could have been issued by typing:
trans-unit.target: This means the last command could have been issued by typing:

trans-unit.source: The **Win32_OperatingSystem** class has many more properties than those displayed here.
trans-unit.target: The **Win32_OperatingSystem** class has many more properties than those displayed here.

trans-unit.source: You can use Get-Member to see all the properties.
trans-unit.target: You can use Get-Member to see all the properties.

trans-unit.source: The properties of a WMI class are automatically available like other object properties:
trans-unit.target: The properties of a WMI class are automatically available like other object properties:

trans-unit.source: Displaying Non-Default Properties with Format Cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Displaying Non-Default Properties with Format Cmdlets

trans-unit.source: If you want information contained in the **Win32_OperatingSystem** class that is not displayed by default, you can display it by using the **Format** cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: If you want information contained in the **Win32_OperatingSystem** class that is not displayed by default, you can display it by using the **Format** cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you want to display available memory data, type:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you want to display available memory data, type:

trans-unit.source: Wildcards work with property names in **Format-Table**, so the final pipeline element can be reduced to **Format-Table -Property TotalV\*,Free\***
trans-unit.target: Wildcards work with property names in **Format-Table**, so the final pipeline element can be reduced to **Format-Table -Property TotalV\*,Free\***
